  - Location p1===from https://journal.kci.go.kr/eih/archive/articleView?artiId=ART002959414

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Korean contemporary art is shaped by the nation’s fast-changing culture and technological advancements, serving as a dynamic reflection of societal transformation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Korean contemporary art stands as a vibrant reflection of the nation’s rapidly evolving culture and technology."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Artists intentionally combine traditional Korean artistic forms and philosophies with modern themes and global trends to create culturally resonant works.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "By intertwining traditional Korean elements with modern influences, this art form has gained international acclaim."  
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: The global spread of South Korean popular culture (e.g., K-pop, cinema, fashion) has directly influenced contemporary artists to incorporate these elements into their artworks.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Consequently, Korean contemporary artists have adeptly integrated elements of K-pop, cinema, and global fashion trends into their works, creating captivating and culturally resonant pieces."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: A majority of contemporary Korean artists use digital platforms like Instagram and TikTok as primary channels to showcase their work and engage with international audiences.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "As of 2022, approximately 60% of Korean contemporary artists use digital platforms as their primary mode of showcasing their work."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Many contemporary art exhibitions in Korea, especially in Seoul, include digital interaction technologies to enhance viewer immersion and engagement.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "By 2023, nearly 70% of newly commissioned exhibitions in Seoul incorporated some form of digital interaction, heightening viewer immersion and experience."  
  - Location paragraph 6===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Korean contemporary artists maintain a deliberate balance between modern innovation and traditional practices such as Dansaekhwa (monochrome painting) and Minhwa (folk painting).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Critical to understanding the influence of modern culture on Korean contemporary art is recognizing the intricate balance artists maintain between innovation and tradition... infusing them with contemporary themes."  
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Rapid urbanization and modernization in South Korea have led artists to explore themes such as identity, migration, displacement, and socio-economic disparities through their work.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The juxtaposition of traditional Korean motifs with modern urban landscapes creates compelling narratives that explore themes of identity, rapid development, and socio-economic disparities resulting from such growth."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Artists utilize virtual reality, augmented reality, robotics, and interactive algorithms to transform passive viewing into active, multisensory participation.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Artists can create immersive environments where viewers can interact with art in multidimensional spaces. This interactivity transforms the traditional passive viewing experience into an engaging and participatory event."  
  - Location paragraph 2 (under “The Impact of Technology on Korean Art”)===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Blockchain and NFTs allow Korean artists to bypass traditional gatekeepers, monetize digital works directly, and maintain provenance in global markets.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Such platforms dismantle traditional gatekeeping structures, allowing artists direct access to global markets and audiences."  
  - Location paragraph 4 (under “The Impact of Technology on Korean Art”)===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Leading Korean contemporary artists often employ conceptual, multidisciplinary approaches—combining sculpture, installation, performance, and technology—to challenge conventional interpretations of art.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "Haegue Yang, whose multidisciplinary practice encompasses sculpture, installation, and performance, continues to challenge traditional interpretations of art."  
  - Location paragraph 6 (under “Key Contemporary Korean Artists to Watch”)===from https://everythingkorea.blog/2025/03/21/exploring-korean-contemporary-art-artists-and-exhibitions/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Korean contemporary art has been promoted to the public and collectors through dedicated art publications initiated by commercial galleries.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "During the 1970s, when Oriental painting dominated the art scene, President Park Myung-ja highlighted Western painting through exhibitions and brought contemporary art to the public and collectors through 'Hwarangji,' which was the first art magazine published by a commercial gallery in Korea."  
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://www.galleryhyundai.com/exhibition/view/20000000059

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Korean experimental contemporary art from the 1960s–1970s has gained significant institutional recognition, both nationally and internationally, through major museum exhibitions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The Experimental artists featured in this exhibition were central figures in Only the Young Experimental Art in Korea, 1960s–1970s, a touring exhibition spanning 2023 and 2024 at the National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, Korea (MMCA), Seoul; Guggenheim Museum, New York; and the Hammer Museum, Los Angeles."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.galleryhyundai.com/exhibition/view/20000000059

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.feature: Diaspora artists have played a significant role in shaping Korean contemporary art, engaging in artistic dialogue with domestic experimental artists while developing independent aesthetic languages.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Art and Ente.original:
- Quoted text "The artistic dialogue between Korean Experimental artists and diaspora artists resonates with a shared pursuit of distinctive aesthetic languages. Yet, like individual constellations, they each build their own independent worlds, representing a vital legacy of Korean modern and contemporary art."  
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.galleryhyundai.com/exhibition/view/20000000059

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The number 4 is considered unlucky and taboo due to its phonetic similarity to the word for death, so it is avoided in contexts such as floor numbering and gift-giving.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "'4'라는 단어의 발음과 한자 '死'' (죽음을 뜻함)이 비슷하기 때문에 불길하고 심지어 불운한 것으로 여겨진다. 엘리베이터에서 4층을 선택하는 것도 불운으로 여겨지기 때문에, 예전에 지어진 건물의 일부는 4층 버튼 없이 지어지기도 했다. 선물도 4의 배수로는 거의 주어지지 않는다."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C%EB%AF%BC%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%98_%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Public kissing is viewed as disrespectful and embarrassing, especially by older generations, although younger adults may be more tolerant.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "공공장소에서 키스를 하는 것은 한국의 나이든 사람들 사이에서 매우 경시되고 무례하게 여겨진다. 이것은 현재의 젊은 성인 세대에 와서는 덜 금기시되었지만, 여전히 널리 권장되지 않으며, 부끄러운 행위로 여겨진다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C%EB%AF%BC%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%98_%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Wearing suitable clothing is seen as a sign of respect, particularly during formal events or when meeting new people, where business attire is appropriate.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "상황에 맞게 옷을 입는 것은 한국에서 존경의 표시로 여겨지기에 매우 중요한 일이다. 일반적으로 새로운 사람들을 만나거나 공식적인 행사가 있을 때는 정장과 넥타이를 매는 것이 적절하다."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C%EB%AF%BC%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%98_%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In Korea, bowing is a common way to greet others and signifies respect, especially toward elders or superiors.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In Korea, people bow when they greet each other. It is a sign of respect, especially to elders or superiors."
  - Location p1===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is considered polite to use both hands when giving or receiving items; using one hand may be seen as rude.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When you give or receive something in Korea, you should use both hands. If you use only one hand, it may seem rude."
  - Location p2===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Respecting elders is crucial in Korean culture, demonstrated by speaking politely and behaving carefully in their presence.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Respecting elders is very important in Korean culture. People speak more politely and behave more carefully around older people."
  - Location p3===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to remove shoes when entering someone’s home, as wearing them indoors is considered impolite.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Koreans take off their shoes when entering a home. Wearing shoes inside someone’s home is considered impolite."
  - Location p4===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Younger individuals wait for elders to start eating first as a sign of respect and good manners.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "At the table, younger people wait for elders to start eating first. It shows respect and good manners."
  - Location p5===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The use of honorifics (polite language forms) is essential in Korean conversations to show appropriate levels of respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The Korean language has polite forms called honorifics. Using the correct level of politeness is very important in conversations."
  - Location p6===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Covering one’s mouth while laughing or yawning is considered polite and shows consideration for others.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In Korea, it’s polite to cover your mouth when you laugh or yawn. It shows consideration for others."
  - Location p7===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: A slight bow is often added when giving something to another person to express respect and make the gesture more courteous.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When giving something, people often bow slightly as a sign of respect. It makes the gesture more polite and thoughtful."
  - Location p8===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Sticking chopsticks upright in a bowl of rice is forbidden because it resembles funeral rituals and is seen as highly disrespectful.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Never stick chopsticks upright into a bowl of rice. It looks like a ritual for the dead and is considered very disrespectful."
  - Location p9===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Accepting a drink should be done with both hands, and when drinking with elders, one should turn their head slightly away as a sign of respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When someone offers you a drink, accept it with two hands. When drinking with elders, turn your head slightly away to drink."
  - Location p10===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Blowing one’s nose during a meal is considered rude; if necessary, one should excuse themselves and do so privately.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Blowing your nose at the table is considered rude in Korea. If you need to blow your nose, excuse yourself and do it in private."
  - Location p11===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Pointing at someone with a finger is considered impolite; instead, Koreans typically use their whole hand to gesture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Pointing at someone with your finger is seen as impolite. Instead, Koreans gesture with their whole hand."
  - Location p12===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When pouring alcohol for elders, placing one hand on the chest shows humility and respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When pouring alcohol for elders, Koreans often place their other hand on their chest. It shows humility and respect."
  - Location p13===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Speaking loudly in public places is considered bad manners, and Koreans aim to be considerate of others in quiet environments.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Speaking loudly in public is considered bad manners. Koreans try to be considerate of others in quiet spaces."
  - Location p14===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Even in informal settings, people usually wait until everyone has been served before starting to eat as a gesture of thoughtfulness.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Even in casual settings, people usually wait until everyone is served before eating. It’s a small gesture of thoughtfulness."
  - Location p15===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Holding the door open for the person behind is considered a polite and appreciated act, especially in schools or offices.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Holding the door open for someone behind you is a polite act in Korea. This small act is appreciated, especially in schools or offices."
  - Location p16===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Koreans value order and patiently wait their turn; cutting in line is viewed as highly disrespectful.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Koreans value order and wait in line patiently. Cutting in line is seen as very disrespectful."
  - Location p17===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Koreans commonly use polite speech (honorifics) even with strangers as a natural way of showing respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Even with strangers, Koreans use polite speech. It’s a natural way to show respect."
  - Location p18===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to offer to pay the bill when dining out, particularly when elders or guests are present, which is seen as polite regardless of later cost-sharing.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When dining out, it’s common to offer to pay the bill, especially for elders or guests. Even if you split the cost later, offering first is polite."
  - Location p19===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In formal settings, maintaining good posture while sitting is important; slouching or spreading legs is considered rude.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In formal situations, sitting with good posture is important. Slouching or spreading your legs may be considered rude."
  - Location p20===from https://wisemomtutor.tistory.com/223

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In Korea, the level of formality in speech (honorifics) depends on the other person’s age and social position. When meeting someone for the first time, it is polite to use formal speech, and people often ask about the other person’s birth year or school year to determine appropriate language use.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Koreans use formal and informal speech depending on the other person’s age and social position. To know which level of formality to use, people commonly ask “Excuse me, but what year were you born?” or “What’s your class year?” when first meeting someone to determine their age. It’s considered polite to use formal speech when meeting someone for the first time. If you speak Korean, always use the polite endings ‘-yo’ or -‘nida’."  
  - Location p2===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: At meals, individuals must wait until the eldest person picks up their utensils before starting to eat, and they typically say “jal meokkesseumnida” before beginning.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "At meals, you wait until the eldest person picks up their utensils before beginning to eat. Usually, you say “jal meokkesseumnida” (I will eat well/Thank you for the meal) before eating quietly without making noise."  
  - Location p3===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: While eating quietly is generally expected, making slurping sounds is acceptable when consuming noodle dishes.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "However, it’s acceptable to make slurping sounds when eating noodles."  
  - Location p3===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is improper to use both spoon and chopsticks at the same time; bowls should remain on the table and not be lifted while eating.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "You don’t use a spoon and chopsticks simultaneously, and bowls must remain on the table while eating."  
  - Location p3===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When greeting someone for the first time or someone deserving respect, it is customary to shake hands with both hands while bowing the head or waist.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When meeting someone for the first time or someone who requires formal respect, you shake hands with both hands and bow your head or waist in greeting."  
  - Location p4===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The degree of bowing indicates the level of respect—90 degrees for highest respect, 45 degrees for general courtesy, and 15 degrees for a light greeting—with deeper bows reserved for elders or superiors.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Bow deeper to elders or superiors"  
  - Location p4===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When exchanging business cards, both hands must be used as a sign of respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Use both hands when exchanging business cards"  
  - Location p4===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In drinking settings, the elder or superior initiates the toast first.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In Korean drinking culture, elders or superiors initiate the toast first..."  
  - Location p5===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is proper etiquette to use both hands when receiving or pouring alcohol, especially in formal or hierarchical contexts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "...you must use both hands when receiving or pouring alcohol..."  
  - Location p5===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Out of respect, one should turn their head away while drinking alcohol in the presence of elders or superiors.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "...while turning your head away when drinking in front of elders."  
  - Location p5===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is considered proper to keep others’ glasses filled and avoid letting them become empty during group drinking sessions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Additionally, it is proper etiquette to keep refilling each other’s glasses without leaving them empty..."  
  - Location p5===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is impolite to pour one’s own drink; instead, drinks should be poured by others as a gesture of mutual respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "...and never pour into your own glass."  
  - Location p5===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is basic etiquette to remove shoes at the entrance when entering a home, and slippers or bare feet are used indoors. This practice also applies in schools, some restaurants, and jjimjilbangs.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is basic etiquette to take off your shoes at the entrance when entering a home and live in slippers or barefoot... students change into indoor shoes at school, some restaurants require removing shoes, and at jjimjilbangs (Korean saunas) you must enter with provided slippers or barefoot..."  
  - Location p6===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is polite to wear socks when visiting someone else’s home or when hosting guests, due to indoor shoe-free customs.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "...and it is polite to wear socks when visiting someone else’s house or when guests come over."  
  - Location p6===from https://vivissem.com/%EB%8F%85%ED%8A%B9%ED%95%9C-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EC%98%88%EC%A0%88-unique-korean-cultural-etiquette/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 한국어에서는 연령, 직위, 사회적 관계에 따라 존댓말과 말투를 조절하는 것이 예의이며, 이는 단순한 언어 사용을 넘어 관계 맺기 방식의 차이로 이해되어야 한다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한국어에는 명확한 위계질서가 언어에 녹아 있습니다. 외국인에게는 '존댓말'이라는 개념 자체도 낯설 수 있지만, 그보다 더 복잡한 문제는 그 말투에 담긴 사회적 거리감과 미묘한 계층 구분입니다."
  - Location p2===from https://innostar100.com/entry/%EC%99%B8%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%B8%EC%97%90%EA%B2%8C-%EC%84%A4%EB%AA%85%ED%95%98%EA%B8%B0-%EC%96%B4%EB%A0%A4%EC%9A%B4-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%8B%9D-%EC%98%88%EC%9D%98%EB%B2%94%EC%A0%88-5%EA%B0%80%EC%A7%80

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 식사 자리에서 윗사람이 먼저 수저를 들기 전까지 기다리는 것은 나이와 권위에 대한 존중을 실천하는 문화적 예의이다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한국에서는 윗사람이 식사를 시작하기 전까지 기다리는 것이 예의입니다."
  - Location p3===from https://innostar100.com/entry/%EC%99%B8%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%B8%EC%97%90%EA%B2%8C-%EC%84%A4%EB%AA%85%ED%95%98%EA%B8%B0-%EC%96%B4%EB%A0%A4%EC%9A%B4-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%8B%9D-%EC%98%88%EC%9D%98%EB%B2%94%EC%A0%88-5%EA%B0%80%EC%A7%80

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 설날이나 추석과 같은 명절에 큰절이나 세배를 하는 것은 조상의 덕을 기리고 가족 간 위계질서를 재확인하는 의례적인 예의 행위이다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "설날이나 추석 같은 전통 명절에는 ‘큰절’이나 ‘세배’와 같은 특별한 인사법이 요구됩니다. 이때의 인사는 단순한 몸짓이 아니라 조상의 덕을 기리고, 가족 간의 위계질서를 재확인하는 의례적 행위입니다."
  - Location p4===from https://innostar100.com/entry/%EC%99%B8%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%B8%EC%97%90%EA%B2%8C-%EC%84%A4%EB%AA%85%ED%95%98%EA%B8%B0-%EC%96%B4%EB%A0%A4%EC%9A%B4-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%8B%9D-%EC%98%88%EC%9D%98%EB%B2%94%EC%A0%88-5%EA%B0%80%EC%A7%80

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 술을 따를 때 두 손으로 따르고, 어른이 주는 술은 고개를 돌려 마시며, 술을 거절할 때도 정중해야 하며 그렇지 않으면 관계에 악영향을 줄 수 있다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "술을 따를 때는 반드시 두 손으로 따라야 예의에 맞는 행동으로 여겨집니다. 또한 술을 마시지 못할 경우에도 정중히 거절해야 하며, 무례하게 거절할 경우 관계에 금이 갈 수 있습니다. 어른이 술을 따르면 고개를 돌리고 마셔야 하며..."
  - Location p5===from https://innostar100.com/entry/%EC%99%B8%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%B8%EC%97%90%EA%B2%8C-%EC%84%A4%EB%AA%85%ED%95%98%EA%B8%B0-%EC%96%B4%EB%A0%A4%EC%9A%B4-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%8B%9D-%EC%98%88%EC%9D%98%EB%B2%94%EC%A0%88-5%EA%B0%80%EC%A7%80

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 한국에서는 방문 시 작은 선물을 준비하는 것이 예의이며, 선물의 가격보다는 성의와 상황에 맞는 선택이 중요하다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한국에서는 누군가를 처음 만날 때, 또는 방문할 때 작은 선물을 준비하는 문화가 존재합니다... 외국인이 한국 친구의 부모님 댁을 방문할 때, 사소한 선물 하나 없이 가는 것은 예의에 어긋나는 것으로 여겨질 수 있습니다. 또 선물을 주는 방식, 받는 자세, 심지어는 포장 방식까지도 의례적 정서와 체면 문화와 연결되어 있습니다."
  - Location p6===from https://innostar100.com/entry/%EC%99%B8%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%B8%EC%97%90%EA%B2%8C-%EC%84%A4%EB%AA%85%ED%95%98%EA%B8%B0-%EC%96%B4%EB%A0%A4%EC%9A%B4-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%8B%9D-%EC%98%88%EC%9D%98%EB%B2%94%EC%A0%88-5%EA%B0%80%EC%A7%80

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In formal or respectful contexts, Koreans historically used "ja" (字), an adult name given at maturity, instead of a person's birth name to show respect and recognize them as an adult.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "자(字)는 사람이 성년이 됐을 때 지어주는 새 이름이다. 이는 그 사람을 한 명의 성인으로 예우하고 존중한다는 의미이다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It was considered rude and vulgar to call someone by their birth name ("myeong") in the presence of peers or elders; instead, the "ja" (adult name) was used as a sign of respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "명은 상대의 이름을 직접적으로 부르는 것은 속되고 무례한 일이지만, 자는 상대를 존중하고 높여 부르는 행위로 여겨졌다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Subordinates were not allowed to casually use the "ja" (adult name) of their superiors; they had to use honorific titles such as “jeonha” or “jokha” instead.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "아랫사람은 윗사람의 자를 함부로 부를 수 없었다. 아랫사람은 윗사람에게 ‘전하’, ‘족하’ 등의 경칭(敬稱)을 사용해야 했다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: "Ho" (號) is a personal alias or pen name that individuals could adopt and change freely, often used alongside one’s real name, and continues to be recognized in modern Korean culture.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "호는 개인의 별명과 같은 것으로 언제든지 바꿀 수 있었다."  
  - Location paragraph 3===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The use of "ho" (號) has persisted into the 21st century, with some public figures introducing themselves using their ho along with their given name, indicating its continued cultural relevance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "21세기인 지금도 ‘도올 김용옥’처럼 미디어에 종종 자신의 호를 이름과 함께 소개하는 사람들이 나오는 것을 보면 호는 현대 사회에서도 그 명맥을 이어가는 한국의 이름 문화라고 할 수 있다."
  - Location paragraph 3===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Out of respect for elders, it is customary not to use the same Chinese characters found in parents' names when naming children, a practice influenced by the tradition of "pihwi" (避諱).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "지금까지도 자녀의 이름을 지을 때, 부모가 사용하는 한자를 쓰지 않으려는 경우가 많은데 이 역시도 윗사람의 이름을 함부로 사용할 수 없다는 피휘의 영향이다."
  - Location paragraph 4===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: During the Joseon Dynasty, even grandparents' names (such as maternal grandfather or grandmother) were subject to avoidance practices, reflecting the strong cultural emphasis on respecting elders through naming conventions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "조선시대에는 부모뿐만 아니라 외조부, 외조모의 이름까지 피휘의 대상이 되기도 하는 등 피휘가 강하게 나타났다."
  - Location paragraph 4===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean names are structured with the family name first, followed by the given name.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Korean naming conventions arrange names as follows [FAMILY NAME] [personal name]."  
  - Location p1===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The family name is inherited patrilineally from the father, shared among siblings, and always precedes the given name. It is typically a single syllable or character.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The family name (or ‘surname’) is inherited patrilineally from one’s father and shared with other siblings. It always comes before the given name and is usually a single syllable/character."  
  - Location p3===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The given name usually consists of two syllables or characters that form a single unit; there is no concept of a middle name in Korean naming.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The given name (or ‘personal name’) usually contains two syllables/characters. Both components of the personal name are considered to be a single unit. The concept of a ‘middle name’ is not followed in South Korea."  
  - Location p4===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Traditionally, one part of a person’s given name is a unique personal identifier while the other is a generation name shared by same-gender siblings within the family.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Traditionally, one component/character of a person’s given name is a unique name chosen at birth as the individual’s personal identifier. The other is a generation name that is typically shared by all siblings of the same gender within a family."  
  - Location p5===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: While the two syllables of a given name may be written together, hyphenated, or separated, it is recommended to write them as a single unit to indicate they form one name.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The two syllables/characters of the given name may be written together, hyphenated or divided into two. For example, 효리 could be written Hyori, Hyo Ri or Hyo-ri. However, it is advisable to write both words as a single unit (e.g. Hyori) to clearly indicate that it is one name."  
  - Location p6===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Single-syllable given names exist but are uncommon in Korean naming practice.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Single-syllable given names exist but are uncommon (e.g. KANG Min (강민) or JO Kwon (조권)."  
  - Location p7===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When written in Hangul, there are no spaces between the family name and given name.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "There are no spaces between a person’s family name and given name when written in the Korean alphabet (hangul), e.g. 김민수 (KIM Min Su)."  
  - Location p8===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Women do not change their legal names upon marriage.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Women do not change their legal names at marriage."  
  - Location p9===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean names romanised into the Latin alphabet can have multiple spelling variations due to different transcription methods, even though the Revised Romanization of Korean is most commonly used.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Be aware that Korean names written in the Roman alphabet have all been transcribed from the original Korean or Chinese characters. There are many different ways to represent these characters in English, which can result in the same Korean name being written with many different spelling variations... The Romanisation system most widely used is the ‘Revised Romanization of Korean’."  
  - Location p10===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Some Koreans reverse the order of their name (given name first, then family name) in international contexts to conform to Western naming conventions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Many Koreans use a ‘Westernised’ version of their original Korean name to adapt to international and English-speaking contexts. This may involve reversing the arrangement of their given name and family name to suit English-Western naming conventions [personal name] [FAMILY NAME]."  
  - Location p11===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Many Koreans adopt an English name for use in international or English-speaking settings, while reverting to their original Korean name in Korean-language or familial contexts.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Many Koreans have an ‘English name’ that they use in international and English-speaking contexts... Most people will revert to using their original Korean name amongst family or when writing or speaking in Korean."  
  - Location p12===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Parents often choose names believed to bring good luck, considering factors like birth date, time, and number of strokes in the Korean characters; some consult shamans or fortune tellers for guidance.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Names may be chosen in accordance with a child’s birth date and time, as well as the number of strokes of the name in Korean characters, to assure it is auspicious. Some parents may consult a shaman/fortune teller to find the luckiest name for a child."  
  - Location p14===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean given names often carry significant meanings reflecting aspirations such as brightness, strength, beauty, or wisdom.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Many Korean given names are instilled with some significant meaning that symbolises aspirations and wishes for the child, e.g. Kyong (brightness), Geon (strong), Cho (beautiful), Young (valiant)."  
  - Location p15===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It has become popular for parents to use native Korean words (typically two or more syllables) as given names, such as Ha-neul (sky/heaven), Areum (beauty), or Seulgi (wisdom).
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "While traditional Korean naming practices are common (i.e. using generation names etc.), it has also become popular for parents to name children using native Korean words (usually two syllables or more). For example, 하늘 Ha-neul (heaven/sky), 아름 Areum (beauty), 슬기 Seulgi (wisdom)."  
  - Location p16===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Given names often reflect traditional gender roles, with female names associated with qualities like beauty or softness, and male names associated with strength, bravery, or ambition.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Korean given names often have a gender-specific meaning relating to traditional gender roles. Female names tend to reflect feminine-associated qualities such as beauty or softness, while male names commonly signify traditional male-associated qualities such as strength, bravery, success or ambition."  
  - Location p17===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is not customary or appropriate to name a child after an elder or family member.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "It is not customary or appropriate to name a child after their elder or family member."  
  - Location p18===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: While most family names are one syllable, some Korean family names consist of two syllables, such as HWANGBO, SEON-U, DOKGO, or NAMGUNG.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "While most Korean family names are one syllable, there are some exceptions (e.g. HWANGBO (황보), SEON-U (선우), DOKGO (독고), NAMGUNG (남궁)."  
  - Location p19===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Each family name is generally linked to one or more clans, and individuals with the same surname may belong to different ancestral clans.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Each family name can generally be traced back to a clan. For example, most people with the surname LEE (李) in Korea belong to either the Jeonju or Gyeongju clans. There are usually multiple different clans related to a family name."  
  - Location p20===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Some Koreans have a religious (e.g., baptismal) name in addition to their legal and English names.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Some Koreans may also have a religious name (different to an English name) that they are given at baptism. For example, KIM Min Su may have the English name ‘Eric’ and the baptismal name ‘Joshua’."  
  - Location p21===from https://culturalatlas.sbs.com.au/south-korean-culture/south-korean-culture-naming

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean male names are more likely to use Sino-Korean (Chinese-character-based) vocabulary, while female names are more likely to use native Korean or foreign-origin words.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한자어 이름은 여성보다 남성이, 고유어나 외래어 이름은 남성보다 여성이 더 높은 비중을 차지하며"
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.kci.go.kr/kciportal/landing/article.kci?arti_id=ART001698689

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Male names frequently end with specific syllables such as "수", "호", "훈", "현", and "준", while female names commonly end in "자", "숙", "순", "희", and "옥".
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "이름 끝 글자의 경우, 남성은 ‘수, 호>훈>현>준’이, 여성은 ‘자, 숙, 순, 희, 옥’ 등이 높은 빈도로 사용되다가"
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.kci.go.kr/kciportal/landing/article.kci?arti_id=ART001698689

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The character "희" has consistently appeared across generations in female names and is recognized as the most enduring component in Korean female naming conventions.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "‘희’가 모든 시대에 공통적으로 출현함으로써 가장 오랫동안 여성 이름을 구성하는 요소로 자리 잡고 있음이 확인되었다."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.kci.go.kr/kciportal/landing/article.kci?arti_id=ART001698689

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Over 98% of Korean names consist of two syllables; one-syllable names are more common among males, while names with three or more syllables are more prevalent among females.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "이름의 음절수를 분석한 결과, 2음절로 이루어진 경우가 98% 이상의 높은 비중을 차지하며, 1음절 이름의 경우는 남성이, 3음절, 4음절 이상의 다음절인 경우는 여성이 훨씬 더 높은 비중을 차지한다는 사실"
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.kci.go.kr/kciportal/landing/article.kci?arti_id=ART001698689

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Male names tend to end in the consonant 'ㄴ', whereas female names are more likely to end in vowels.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "이름의 끝 음절 말음으로 선택되는 음 가운데 가장 높은 비중을 차지하는 것은 ‘ㄴ’이나 ‘모음’이며, 남성은 모음보다는 자음 ‘ㄴ’이, 여성은 ‘ㄴ’보다 모음으로 끝나는 비중이 더 높게 나타난다는 사실이 확인되었다."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://www.kci.go.kr/kciportal/landing/article.kci?arti_id=ART001698689

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean names are composed of a family name (surname) followed by a given name, with the family name typically being one syllable and the given name usually consisting of two syllables.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한국어 이름은 성과 이름으로 이루어져 있으며, 보통 성은 한 글자, 이름은 두 글자로 구성됩니다."
  - Location p2===from https://efhi.tistory.com/entry/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%96%B4-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%9D%98-%EA%B5%AC%EC%A1%B0%EC%99%80-%EC%9D%98%EB%AF%B8

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The two syllables in a Korean given name are typically based on Chinese characters (Hanja), each carrying a distinct meaning that often reflects parents' aspirations or values for the child.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한국 이름의 두 글자는 보통 한자로 표현되며, 각각 고유한 의미를 가집니다. 예를 들어 ‘민준’이라는 이름은 ‘민(敏)’이 ‘민첩함’, ‘준(俊)’이 ‘재능’을 뜻합니다. 부모님은 이름을 통해 아이에게 바라는 소망과 가치관을 표현하곤 합니다."
  - Location p2===from https://efhi.tistory.com/entry/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%96%B4-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%9D%98-%EA%B5%AC%EC%A1%B0%EC%99%80-%EC%9D%98%EB%AF%B8

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Names within a family may share common Hanja characters or similar sounds to emphasize familial continuity and connection across generations.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한 가문 내에서 특정 한자를 공유하거나 비슷한 발음을 가진 이름을 짓기도 합니다. 이렇게 이름을 통해 가족의 유대감을 표현하는 방식은 서양의 작명법과 비교해 특별한 느낌을 줍니다."
  - Location p3===from https://efhi.tistory.com/entry/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%96%B4-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%9D%98-%EA%B5%AC%EC%A1%B0%EC%99%80-%EC%9D%98%EB%AF%B8

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In global contexts, Korean names are adapted using the standard Romanization system of South Korea, allowing for international recognition while preserving the original pronunciation as closely as possible.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "대한민국 표준 로마자 표기법에 따라 이름을 변환할 수 있습니다. 예 ‘정민’은 ‘Jeong Min’으로 표기됩니다."
  - Location p4===from https://efhi.tistory.com/entry/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%96%B4-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%9D%98-%EA%B5%AC%EC%A1%B0%EC%99%80-%EC%9D%98%EB%AF%B8

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 한국 전통 문화에서 개인이 성년이 되면 이름 대신 사용할 수 있는 ‘자(字)’를 붙여주었으며, 이는 그 사람을 성인으로 예우하고 존중하는 의미를 담고 있었다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "자는 사람이 성년이 됐을 때 지어주는 새 이름이다. 이는 그 사람을 한 명의 성인으로 예우하고 존중한다는 의미이다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 태어날 때 지은 본명(명)은 손윗사람이 아닌 경우 함부로 부르는 것이 무례로 여겨졌기 때문에, 동료나 동년배는 상대의 명 대신 자를 사용하여 격식을 차렸다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "명은 상대의 이름을 직접적으로 부르는 것은 속되고 무례한 일이지만, 자는 상대를 존중하고 높여 부르는 행위로 여겨졌다. 따라서 윗사람은 아랫사람의 명을 편하게 부를 수 있었지만, 동료나 동년배는 관습에 따라 격식을 갖춰 명 대신 자를 불렀다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: ‘호’는 개인이 자유롭게 선택하고 변경할 수 있는 별칭으로, 당나라 이후 한국에 전래되어 근현대까지 이어졌으며, 현대에도 일부 인물들이 자신의 호를 이름과 함께 사용함으로써 전통이 유지되고 있다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "자는 손윗사람이 내려주는 것이었고 한 번 정해지면 바꾸기 힘든 것이었지만 호는 개인의 별명과 같은 것으로 언제든지 바꿀 수 있었다."  
  - Location paragraph 3
- ===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 조상, 부모, 국왕 등 윗사람의 이름을 직접 부르거나 쓰는 것을 피하는 ‘피휘’ 관습이 존재하였으며, 이는 문서 작성 시 해당 한자를 생략하거나 다른 글자로 대체하는 방식으로 실천되었다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "피휘는 사람을 부를 때 그의 명을 직접 입에 올리는 것이 아니라 돌려서 지칭하던 동아시아 고유의 관습을 말한다. 문서에서 임금의 이름과 같은 한자가 직접 등장하는 경우 이를 다른 한자로 바꿔 읽거나 획의 일부를 생략해 표기하는 것을 말한다."
  - Location paragraph 4===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 조선 왕가에서는 백성들이 흔히 사용하는 한자를 피하여 자녀의 이름을 복잡하고 드문 ‘벽자’로 지음으로써, 피휘로 인한 일반인의 부담을 줄이고자 하였다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "조선 왕가는 왕자들의 이름을 획순이 복잡하고 백성들이 자주 사용하지 않는 ‘벽자(僻字)’로 지었다."
  - Location paragraph 5===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 오늘날에도 자녀의 이름을 지을 때 부모가 사용하는 한자를 피하려는 경향이 있으며, 이는 과거 피휘 관습의 영향에서 비롯된 것이다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "우리나라는 지금까지도 자녀의 이름을 지을 때, 부모가 사용하는 한자를 쓰지 않으려는 경우가 많은데 이 역시도 윗사람의 이름을 함부로 사용할 수 없다는 피휘의 영향이다."
  - Location paragraph 5===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Names in ancient Korea, particularly before the Three Kingdoms period, were often derived from natural surroundings or myths, reflecting individual characteristics or origin stories.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "삼국시대 이전에는 이름이 주로 주변 자연환경이나 신화에서 유래되었습니다. ‘박혁거세’는 박 속에서 태어났다는 신화에서 유래한 이름입니다."
  - Location p5===from https://efhi.tistory.com/entry/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%96%B4-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%9D%98-%EA%B5%AC%EC%A1%B0%EC%99%80-%EC%9D%98%EB%AF%B8

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: During the Joseon Dynasty, naming practices were influenced by Neo-Confucianism, with names symbolizing family status and personal destiny, and often incorporating characters used by ancestors to emphasize familial continuity.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "조선시대에 들어서면서 성리학의 영향을 받은 작명법이 등장합니다. 이름은 가문의 품격과 개인의 운명을 상징하는 중요한 요소로 자리 잡았습니다. 조상 이름과 비슷한 한자를 사용하여 가족과의 연속성을 강조하기도 했습니다."
  - Location p6===from https://efhi.tistory.com/entry/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%96%B4-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%9D%98-%EA%B5%AC%EC%A1%B0%EC%99%80-%EC%9D%98%EB%AF%B8

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: During the Japanese colonial period, many Koreans were forced to adopt Japanese-style names due to the “Changssi Gaemyeong” policy, but after liberation, traditional Korean names were restored.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "일제 강점기에는 창씨개명 정책으로 인해 많은 한국인이 일본식 이름으로 바뀌는 아픔을 겪었습니다. 그러나 광복 이후에는 전통적인 한국 이름이 복구되었고, 최근에는 순우리말 이름도 인기를 얻고 있습니다."
  - Location p7===from https://efhi.tistory.com/entry/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%96%B4-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%9D%98-%EA%B5%AC%EC%A1%B0%EC%99%80-%EC%9D%98%EB%AF%B8

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 한국 전통 이름 지을 때, 아이의 사주에서 부족한 오행 기운을 보완하기 위해 해당 오행과 관련된 한자를 이름에 포함시킨다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "사주를 분석하여 아이에게 부족하거나 보완이 필요한 오행의 기운을 파악한 뒤, 그 요소를 채워줄 수 있는 한자를 이름에 넣는 방식입니다. 예를 들어 사주 상 “물의 기운”이 약하면 물을 의미하거나 물과 관련된 한자(江 강, 河 하, 海 해 등)를 사용하여 부족한 부분을 보충하는 식입니다."
  - Location p1===from https://baby-name.kr/%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%A0%95%EB%B3%B4/%EC%A0%84%ED%86%B5%EC%A0%81%EC%9D%B8-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EC%95%84%EA%B8%B0-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84-%EC%9E%91%EB%AA%85-%EB%B0%A9%EC%8B%9D%EC%97%90-%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C-%EC%9D%B4%ED%95%B4/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 이름을 지을 때 두 글자의 한자가 모두 음 또는 양이 되지 않도록 음양이 균형 잡히게 조합하는 것을 중요하게 여긴다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "전통적으로 획수나 자형(字形)에 따라 한자가 음(陰) 또는 양(陽)의 기운을 가진다고 보며, 이름 두 글자의 음양 조화가 이뤄지도록 합니다. ... 모두 음의 기운이면 소극적일 수 있다고 여겨져 음양이 균형을 이루게 배합합니다."
  - Location p2===from https://baby-name.kr/%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%A0%95%EB%B3%B4/%EC%A0%84%ED%86%B5%EC%A0%81%EC%9D%B8-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EC%95%84%EA%B8%B0-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84-%EC%9E%91%EB%AA%85-%EB%B0%A9%EC%8B%9D%EC%97%90-%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C-%EC%9D%B4%ED%95%B4/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 이름에는 복, 슬기, 빛 등 긍정적이고 좋은 의미를 지닌 한자를 선택하고, 악할 악(惡), 죽을 사(死), 병 병(病)처럼 부정적인 의미의 한자는 피한다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "이름에 쓰이는 한자들 대부분은 복, 길(吉), 슬기, 빛 등 밝고 좋은 의미를 가진 글자를 선택하며, 부정적 의미의 한자들은 배제하는 것이 원칙입니다. ... 당연히 이러한 글자는 이름자로 사용을 피하는 것이 바람직합니다. 대신 ‘높을 고(高)’, ‘빛날 휘(輝)’, ‘좋을 량(良)’처럼 길하고 아름다운 뜻을 지닌 한자를 택해 아이의 앞날에 긍정적인 의미를 부여합니다."
  - Location p2===from https://baby-name.kr/%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%A0%95%EB%B3%B4/%EC%A0%84%ED%86%B5%EC%A0%81%EC%9D%B8-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EC%95%84%EA%B8%B0-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84-%EC%9E%91%EB%AA%85-%EB%B0%A9%EC%8B%9D%EC%97%90-%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C-%EC%9D%B4%ED%95%B4/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 같은 가문 내에서 세대를 나타내기 위해 공통으로 사용하는 항렬자를 이름에 포함시키며, 이를 통해 가족 간의 계보와 결속을 표현한다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "항렬자는 한 가문의 같은 세대 구성원들이 이름에 공통으로 사용하는 글자를 가리키며, 형제나 사촌끼리 이름 한 글자가 같도록 해서 같은 항렬(세대)임을 드러냅니다. ... 항렬자를 통한 작명은 가문의 결속을 다지는 장치이기도 해서, 전통 사회에서는 이를 따르는 것을 가문에 대한 예의로 여겼습니다."
  - Location p3===from https://baby-name.kr/%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%A0%95%EB%B3%B4/%EC%A0%84%ED%86%B5%EC%A0%81%EC%9D%B8-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EC%95%84%EA%B8%B0-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84-%EC%9E%91%EB%AA%85-%EB%B0%A9%EC%8B%9D%EC%97%90-%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C-%EC%9D%B4%ED%95%B4/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 일부 가문에서는 항렬자를 정할 때 목→화→토→금→수의 오행 상생 순환 원리를 따르며, 5세대 후 다시 처음으로 반복하는 방식을 사용한다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "많은 가문에서 오행 상생의 순환 원리를 따랐습니다. 예를 들어 어떤 집안에서 1세대에 木의 뜻이 담긴 글자를 항렬로 삼았다면, 2세대는 火, 3세대는 土, 4세대는 金, 5세대는 水 순으로 쓰고 다시 6세대에 木으로 돌아가는 식입니다."
  - Location p3===from https://baby-name.kr/%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%A0%95%EB%B3%B4/%EC%A0%84%ED%86%B5%EC%A0%81%EC%9D%B8-%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EC%95%84%EA%B8%B0-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84-%EC%9E%91%EB%AA%85-%EB%B0%A9%EC%8B%9D%EC%97%90-%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C-%EC%9D%B4%ED%95%B4/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean names are predominantly derived from Sino-Korean (Hanja) characters, with this origin being especially prevalent among males compared to females.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Research results, Hanja-based names occupy an overwhelmingly high proportion, and Hanja-based names are more common among males than females..."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.kci.go.kr/kciportal/landing/article.kci?arti_id=ART001698689

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Female names are more likely than male names to originate from native Korean words or foreign languages.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "...native Korean or foreign-origin names are more common among females than males."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://www.kci.go.kr/kciportal/landing/article.kci?arti_id=ART001698689

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 한국인의 이름 대부분은 한자 기반으로 만들어지며, 특히 역사적으로 중국에서 성 + 이름 형태의 작명 방식이 도입되면서 정착되었다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "그러다 중국에서 1글자 또는 2글자로 성씨를 짓는 방식이 들어오고 당시엔 한글이 생기기 전이니 기존 순우리말 이름을 한자로 대신 압축 표기하여 성+이름 총 2~4글자 정도로 짓는 방식이 정착하였다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://namu.wiki/w/%EC%9E%91%EB%AA%85/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 삼국시대 이전 고대 한국인들의 이름은 대부분 고유어(순우리말) 기반으로 구성되어 있었으며, 출신 마을 이름이 성씨의 역할을 하였다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "남북국 시대 이전까지만 해도 고대인들의 인명은 대부분 고유어로 구성되어 있었다. 대체로 삼국시대에 나오는 거의 모든 이름들은 순우리말 기반이다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://namu.wiki/w/%EC%9E%91%EB%AA%85/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 일제강점기 동안 창씨개명 정책으로 인해 일본식 이름이 강제로 사용되었으며, 이로 인해 '미자', '순자' 등 일본 여자 이름 형식의 이름이 대거 생성되었다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "1930년대 이후에는 창씨개명이 강제되면서 일본식 이름이 대거 지어졌다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://namu.wiki/w/%EC%9E%91%EB%AA%85/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 그리스도교 집안에서는 자녀의 이름을 성경 속 인물이나 성인의 이름에서 따르는 전통이 있으며, 천주교 신자 중 일부는 세례명을 법적 이름으로 사용한다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "그리스도교 집안 부모들은 자녀의 이름을 성인(聖人)의 이름이나 성경 속에서 따서 짓는 경우도 있다. 사실 이게 가장 대표적인 사례다. 천주교 집안에서는 세례명을 그대로 주민등록상의 이름으로 삼는 경우가 드물지 않다."
  - Location paragraph 4.4===from https://namu.wiki/w/%EC%9E%91%EB%AA%85/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 한국의 "성(姓)"은 부계 혈통을 나타내는 집단 호칭으로, 아버지의 성을 평생 따르며 바뀌지 않는다. 반면 "씨(氏)"는 동일한 혈통 내에서 각 지역에 분산된 파벌을 구분하기 위한 표지로, 땅과 관련된 개념이며 본관과 유사하다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "성(姓)은 출생의 혈통을 나타내는 집단의 호칭이다. ... 한국에서 성은 부계 혈통의 표지로 쓰여 아버지의 성을 따르고 평생 바뀌는 일이 없었다. 이에 대해, 씨(氏)란 동일 혈통의 사람들이 각지에 분산될 때에 각 지역에 분산된 일파를 표시하기 위한 표지였다. 즉, 씨는 핏줄이 아니라 땅과 연계되어 있는 개념으로, 한국의 본(本)과 유사하다."
  - Location paragraph 1===from https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%98_%EC%84%B1%EC%94%A8%EC%99%80_%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 한국의 성씨 사용은 한자 등 중국 문물이 수입되면서 도입되었으며, 정치적 신분을 나타내는 표지로 처음 사용되었다. 고대 삼국 시대에는 지배층 중심으로 사성(賜姓) 제도를 통해 성씨가 하사되었다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한국에서 성씨가 사용되기 시작한 정확한 시기는 알 수 없으나, 한자(漢字) 등 중국 문물이 수입되었던 시기에 그와 함께 도입되었을 것으로 추정된다. 씨족 사회와 그 집단을 통치하는 지배자 계급이 발생함으로써 정치적 신분을 나타내는 표지로 쓰이게 되었다."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%98_%EC%84%B1%EC%94%A8%EC%99%80_%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 한국의 성씨는 주로 중국의 성씨 제도를 차용하였으며, 일부는 중국 인물을 조상으로 모시거나 중국 성씨를 빌려 와 가문의 권위를 높이는 경향이 있다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한국의 성씨는 삼국 시대 이후 이두식 이름을 쓰다가 7세기 이후에 중국의 성씨제도를 차용한 것이 많다."  
  - Quoted text "다만, 모화사상(慕華思想)의 영향으로 대부분의 성씨가 가문의 권위를 높히기 위해 중국 성씨를 빌려 오거나 실제 조상이 아닌 중국 인물을 시조로 모시거나 했기 때문에 선계를 고증할 수 없는 경우에는 세계가 확실한 파조나 1세조를 실질적인 시조로 보는 것이 합리적이다."
  - Location paragraph 3 (first quote), paragraph 4 (second quote)===from https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%98_%EC%84%B1%EC%94%A8%EC%99%80_%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 한국의 외래 성씨는 중국, 몽골, 여진, 베트남, 일본, 네덜란드 등 다양한 국가에서 유래했으며, 귀화한 자들에게는 김씨 등 기존 성씨가 하사되거나 새로운 성이 등록된다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "외래 성씨는 중국에서 빌려온 성씨·몽골·여진 ·위구르 ·아랍 ·베트남·일본·네덜란드 등이 있으며 대체로 중국 문화가 유행할 당시 중국의 성씨를 빌려와 사용을 하였다."
  - Quoted text "세종은 귀화한 여진족 수백 명에게 김씨 성을 하사했다."
  - Location paragraph 5 (first quote), paragraph 6 (second quote)===from https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%98_%EC%84%B1%EC%94%A8%EC%99%80_%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 현대 한국에서는 자녀가 기본적으로 아버지의 성을 따르며, 새로운 성을 임의로 만들 수 없고, 성과 본관은 법적으로 고정된다. 다만 2008년부터는 부모의 협의에 따라 어머니의 성을 따를 수도 있다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "대한민국과 조선민주주의인민공화국에서는 자녀는 아버지의 성을 따르는 것이 원칙이며, 귀화인이 아닌 이상 임의로 새로운 성을 만들 수 없다.(창성불허)"
  - Quoted text "2005년에 개정된 민법에 따라 2008년 1월 1일부터는 부모가 혼인신고 시에 어머니의 성과 본을 따르기로 협의한 경우에는 자녀가 어머니의 성을 따를 수 있고"
  - Location paragraph 7 (first quote), paragraph 8 (second quote)===from https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%98_%EC%84%B1%EC%94%A8%EC%99%80_%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 성인이 된 후에는 태어날 때 지은 이름(명) 대신 존중을 표현하기 위해 새로 붙이는 자(字)를 사용하여 부르는 것이 관례였다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "자는 사람이 성년이 됐을 때 지어주는 새 이름이다. 이는 그 사람을 한 명의 성인으로 예우하고 존중한다는 의미이다."
  - Location paragraph number (p2)

- Rule Description 윗사람은 아랫사람의 본래 이름(명)을 직접 불러도 되지만, 동료나 동년배는 명을 부르는 것을 금기시하고 자(字)를 사용해야 했다.  
- ===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 조상, 부모, 국왕 등 윗사람의 이름은 직접 발음하거나 문서에 쓰는 것을 피하며, 필요 시 다른 표현이나 한자로 대체하거나 일부 획을 생략하는 관행이 있었다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "문서에서 임금의 이름과 같은 한자가 직접 등장하는 경우 이를 다른 한자로 바꿔 읽거나 획의 일부를 생략해 표기하는 것을 말한다."
  - Location paragraph number (p3)

- Rule Description 왕실은 백성들의 이름 짓는 데 어려움이 없도록 자주 쓰지 않는 복잡한 한자(벽자)로 왕자들의 이름을 지었으며, 이는 윗사람의 이름을 함부로 사용하지 않으려는 피휘 문화의 일환으로 나타났다.  
- ===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: 호는 개인이 스스로 지을 수 있는 별칭으로, 언제든지 변경 가능하며, 자와 달리 격식보다는 개인적 정체성이나 취향을 반영했다.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "자는 손윗사람이 내려주는 것이었고 한 번 정해지면 바꾸기 힘든 것이었지만 호는 개인의 별명과 같은 것으로 언제든지 바꿀 수 있었다."
  - Location paragraph number (p2)

- Rule Description 현대에도 일부 인물들은 자신의 호를 이름과 함께 공개하며, 이는 한국의 이름 문화가 계속 이어지고 있음을 보여준다.  
- ===from http://hiupress.hongik.ac.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=10997

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean names and surnames carry deep cultural meaning, and changing one's surname is considered a serious matter because Koreans typically retain the same surname from birth to death.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한국에서는 결혼을 하여도 성을 바꾸지 않습니다. 사실상 태어나서 죽을 때까지 같은 성으로 살아갑니다. 당연히 성을 바꾸는 것은 심각한 문제가 됩니다."
  - Location p3

- Rule Description Korean names often include generational markers (dorimja), which are used to indicate family hierarchy and generational relationships, sometimes more importantly than age.
- ===from https://www.dongponews.net/news/articleView.html?idxno=51303

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Each syllable in a Korean name carries a specific meaning, often representing positive concepts or virtues, and the combination of syllables is intended to express desirable qualities or aspirations for the child.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Korean names often have profound meanings that go beyond their mere phonetic sound. Each syllable in a name can represent a different concept or symbol, imbuing the name with layers of significance."
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-cultural-significance-of-korean-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean names are chosen to honor ancestors and maintain family continuity, often including shared syllables across generations to reflect generational lineage and familial heritage.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Traditionally, a child’s name is often chosen to honor a specific ancestor or to continue a family naming tradition. This practice ensures a sense of continuity and respect for one’s heritage, while also strengthening the bonds between generations."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-cultural-significance-of-korean-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: In formal or social settings, using a person’s full name is a customary practice to show respect, while using nicknames or abbreviations is considered impolite and indicative of disrespect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "In social settings, it is customary to address someone using their full name or a proper title to show respect. Using abbreviations or nicknames is considered impolite, as it suggests a lack of regard for the person’s identity and social standing."
  - Location paragraph 4===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-cultural-significance-of-korean-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Parents often select names with positive meanings that reflect their hopes for their child’s character and future success, believing the name may influence the child’s destiny.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Another reason why Korean names are important is because they can carry the hopes and aspirations of parents. Parents often choose names with positive meanings or associations, as they believe it may shape the character and future of their child."
  - Location paragraph 8===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-cultural-significance-of-korean-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: The family name, placed before the given name, represents one’s ancestry and lineage, connecting the individual to both their immediate family and the broader Korean community.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The family name, which comes before the given name, represents one’s ancestry and lineage. It not only connects a person to their immediate family but also to the larger Korean community."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-cultural-significance-of-korean-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean names often incorporate Hanja (Chinese) characters, which are carefully selected to add cultural, historical, or aspirational meaning to the name.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Korean names often contain hanja characters, which are Chinese characters used in the Korean writing system. These characters can add another layer of meaning to a name. Hanja characters are chosen carefully to reflect the values and aspirations of the family."
  - Location paragraph 13===from https://namesflare.com/exploring-the-meaning-and-cultural-significance-of-korean-names/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean names are predominantly composed of two syllables, with over 98% of names following this structure, indicating a strong cultural preference for brevity and balance in naming.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "2음절로 이루어진 경우가 98% 이상의 높은 비중을 차지하며"
  - Location paragraph 5

- Rule Description The choice of final consonants or vowels in the last syllable of names differs by gender, with male names more likely to end in the consonant 'ㄴ' and female names more likely to end in vowels, reflecting gender-specific naming patterns.
- ===from https://www.kci.go.kr/kciportal/landing/article.kci?arti_id=ART001698689

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Korean names are composed of a surname and a given name, with the given name typically consisting of two characters that carry specific meanings, often expressed through Hanja (Chinese characters), reflecting parents' hopes and values for their child.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "한국어 이름은 성과 이름으로 이루어져 있으며, 보통 성은 한 글자, 이름은 두 글자로 구성됩니다."  
  - Location p2  

- Rule Description Each syllable in a two-character given name usually corresponds to a Hanja character with its own distinct meaning, and parents use these meanings to express aspirations such as intelligence or talent for their child.  
- ===from https://efhi.tistory.com/entry/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD%EC%96%B4-%EC%9D%B4%EB%A6%84%EC%9D%98-%EA%B5%AC%EC%A1%B0%EC%99%80-%EC%9D%98%EB%AF%B8

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to remove shoes when entering homes, traditional restaurants, and some other establishments like cafes or saunas as a sign of respect and hygiene.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Shoe removal in Korea is both a hygiene rule and a sign of respect. Shoes come off at home, in traditional restaurants, and even at some cafes or saunas."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://kcontenthub.com/en/korean-etiquette-essentials-10-core-rules-from-sharing-to-gift-giving-and-shoe-customs/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When uncertain about whether to remove shoes, individuals should look for physical cues such as a shoe rack at the entrance to determine proper etiquette.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Not sure what to do? Look for a shoe rack at the entrance."
  - Location paragraph 3===from https://kcontenthub.com/en/korean-etiquette-essentials-10-core-rules-from-sharing-to-gift-giving-and-shoe-customs/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Visitors should remove their shoes when entering homes, traditional restaurants, or temples as a sign of politeness and respect.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Take off shoes when entering homes, traditional restaurants, or temples. Wear socks to stay polite."
  - Location paragraph 7===from https://koreawanderlust.tistory.com/48

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Visitors must remove their shoes when entering a residential unit, such as someone’s home or an Airbnb.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Always take off your shoes at the door when entering a residential unit, whether it’s someone’s home or the Airbnb you’re staying in."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://polyglotpetra.com/dos-and-donts-in-korea-for-visitors/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Shoes should be removed when dining at traditional Korean restaurants where guests sit on the floor.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Take them off when dining at more traditional restaurants where guests sit on the floor, too."  
  - Location paragraph 2===from https://polyglotpetra.com/dos-and-donts-in-korea-for-visitors/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: It is customary to remove shoes before entering a Korean home or traditional restaurant as a sign of respect and to maintain cleanliness.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "When visiting a Korean home or a traditional restaurant, it is customary to remove your shoes before entering. This practice is deeply rooted in Korean culture as a way to maintain cleanliness and show respect."  
  - Location paragraph 10===from https://drill.koreacompass.com/blog/2025/08/03/korean-etiquette-10-key-customs-every-visitor-should-know/

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Visitors should wear clean socks when removing shoes, as this is considered a small but important gesture of good manners in situations where shoe removal is expected.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "Wear clean socks. Taking off your shoes is common in many indoor settings, and this small gesture is seen as a sign of good manners."

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: When invited to a meal at a Korean home, it is important to express gratitude for the invitation and follow the host's guidance when choosing a seat.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Traditionally, elders sit in the honored seat (such as the innermost or most comfortable position), while younger or lower-status individuals sit closer to the door; however, it is acceptable to ask the host where to sit.

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: After finishing the meal, one should express appreciation by saying “정말 맛있었습니다” (It was really delicious).

Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.feature: Gifts in Korea are traditionally wrapped in bojagi, a special Korean cloth, with color symbolism playing an important role—red and pink represent good fortune and happiness, blue signifies stability and peace, and white is generally avoided due to its association with mourning.
Personal_Choices_and_Habits-Etiquette an.original:
- Quoted text "The presentation of a gift in Korea is just as important as the gift itself, with special attention given to wrapping and etiquette. Gifts are often wrapped in bojagi (보자기), a traditional Korean cloth for wrapping and carrying items. The colors of the bojagi hold symbolic meanings — red and pink represent good fortune and happiness, while blue signifies stability and peace. White, although commonly associated with purity, is often avoided as it can also symbolize mourning."
  - Location paragraph 5===from https://seoulgoodis.com/blogs/news/korean-gift-giving-culture
